children.subject: Agree completely with anon^. Same lol I had around a 3.9 upper div EECS gpa, then got wrecked with a B- in 127 with Bayen. Just make sure it doesn't happen again and the grade in one particular class won't really matter for a generic cs role.

I think you're already taking the right steps, i.e. looking back and reflecting on the cause of the poor performance. To complete that process, do the obvious but right things: ask what can you do to prevent a repeat of the same situation in the future. 

To answer your second question, it won't ruin your chances of getting internships or jobs, but continuing the theme, you need to ensure it does not happen again. Make this occurrence a rare event, and it won't really affect you in job hunting (I have a few friends that did similarly in some classes yet they currently have great job offers waiting for them). The only issue would probably be if you want to find a job in finance which involves a lot of portfolio optimization, in which case a C+ in optimization would hurt you a lot, but I don't see any other reasonable situation where it hurts you significantly.

Got a similar grade as OP in 127 :(

I wondering would this however ruin chance of grad school (masters) or 5th year masters program? My overall and technical GPA are still above 3.5, but I am worried a C+ in a technical class will not look good on the application. Part of the reason was due to taking 21 units this semester (4 of them research), along with recruiting and family issues.
Hi Heather, for the MEng in EECS is it the same case? Do they care a lot about research connections?

For 5th year master's they look for a 3.5 or above GPA, and, more than anything, a strong connection with one of the faculty members, with whom you're going to do your research project. So let that one bad grade go, and focus on developing your research connections.

history.content: GPA is nearly irrelevant for getting a job once you have any experience. And it gets more irrelevant as you get older

I got a C+ in EE 127 as I struggled a lot with the material this semester, and I probably didn't have the mathematical background to be able to understand the content well enough. :( What should I do to move on from a bad grade? I wasn't currently planning on grad school, but will this ruin my chances of getting internships or jobs in the future? Any advice would be great. Thanks!
history.subject: How to recover from a bad grade?
